awd_titl_txt: SSTLC:   Supporting STEM Teaching and Learning through Communities
awd_abstract_narration: The University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMA) Noyce TF/MTF project, S2TLC: Supporting STEM Teaching and Learning through Communities, responds to the critical need for middle and high school teachers of science and mathematics through a collaboration among the UMA Department of Teacher Education and Curriculum Studies (TECS), the College of Natural Sciences (CNS) and College of Engineering (COE), local high-need middle and high schools in the Pioneer Valley of western Massachusetts (Springfield Public Schools, Holyoke Public Schools, Greenfield Public Schools and Mahar Regional School), and the Hitchcock Center for the Environment, a nonprofit organization focused on the professional development of teachers and the education of youth in the sciences.  The project is encouraging talented science and mathematics students and professionals to pursue teaching careers and develop a long-term commitment to teaching students in high-need secondary schools.  A dynamic and interactive community of 20 Master Teacher Fellows (MTFs) and 20 Teacher Fellows (TFs) are receiving  professional development, community support, licensure, graduate degrees/certificates and salary supplements while they teach in high-need schools. S2TLC is providing inservice secondary mathematics and science teachers (MTFs) with professional development in effective inquiry-based, place-based, and culturally responsive instructional practices and leadership and mentoring skills.  In collaboration with MTFs and partnership schools, the institution is revising and implementing an initial licensure teacher program for secondary mathematics and science teachers in order to better ensure their retention in the profession and successful instruction.  Virtual and face-to-face communities of practice provide MTFs, TFs and other teachers with support for effective instruction and lessen the traditional isolation of classroom teachers.  The project is developing mathematics and science content courses that integrate the use of cognitive technological tools to facilitate learning.  This project is creating a community of practice that grows over time to connect a wide range of stakeholders across districts to educate, challenge, and sustain teachers as leaders and community members. Through a network of teachers in urban and rural schools, it is expected to increase the understanding of how varying contexts impact the manifestation of changes in practice, as well as student experience of these practices.

por.por_cntn:
The Supporting STEM Teaching and Learning through Communities (S2TLC) project was a Master Teaching Fellow (MTF)/Teaching Fellow (TF) six-year initiative designed by a team from the University of Massachusetts Amherst, four western Massachusetts school districts, and other university and community partners to

  • provide in-service secondary mathematics and science teachers (MTFs) with professional development in effective inquiry-, place-based, and culturally responsive instructional practices and leadership and mentoring skills;
  • in collaboration with MTFs and partnership schools, revise and implement an initial licensure teacher program for secondary mathematics and science teachers in order to better ensure their retention in the profession and successful instruction;
  • develop virtual and face-to-face communities of practice to provide MTFs, TFs and other teachers with support for effective instruction and to lessen the traditional isolation of teachers;
  • develop mathematics and science content courses to improve teacher content knowledge for teaching.

By 2017, the project had attended to its original goals and met its obligation of recruiting and supporting 20 MTF/TF pairs with 11 pairs in mathematics and 9 in science. These 20 pairs were spread across rural and urban contexts as well as middle and high school settings.

Thirty-nine of 40 teachers (20 MTFs, 19 TFs) successfully completed the initial training/mentorship aspect of the project. Three of the 19 successful TFs went on to be employed in S2TLC partner districts, a finding that was disappointing to districts, but the remaining TFs found employment following their completion of the licensure/master's program. The majority began teaching in high need schools. For approximately half of the TFs, teaching in high need schools was inordinately challenging, even though they were generally well-prepared to do so. Teachers reported many physical and institutional issues in their schools that made retention problematic. Even with support, about half of the TFs either moved to non-high need schools or left the profession entirely before meeting their teaching obligation.  Attempts to foster face-to-face and virtual communities of practice were generally successful, but not sustainable. Teachers in this cohort bonded and enjoyed their work together; however, it appeared at times they were meeting the obligations of the their commitment to the project as opposed to substantively engaging with one another around issues of practice. Many MTFs eventually assumed additional leadership roles in their districts. In retrospect, this project may have benefitted from a full year to work with prospective MTFs prior to mentoring TFs.

Using lessons learned, a second cohort of 5 experimental MTFs and 5 experimental TFs (all in mathematics) were recruited in 2017 and supported in a program of study similar to the first cohort. All 5 pairs successfully completed the program of study and began teaching following the initial licensure/master's program. One major difference in the execution of this experience was the requirement for MTFs and TFs to complete three common graduate courses and to earn a B or better to continue. This slight variation lead to greater engagement and concern, especially around content that was challenging either mathematically, pedagogically, or technologically. In the original cohort, though participation in courses was required, graduate credit for MTFs was not required and that was an important lesson for the project.

Building on prior communities of practice experiences, Dinner and Dialogue sessions were instituted in 2019 (5 2017 TFs, 2 2012 TFs). These face-to-face two-hour sessions across the academic year included a variety of induction and leadership experiences. Over the next 2.5 years, D&Ds were expanded to include MTFs. With the arrival of COVID, D&Ds morphed into virtual sessions on Zoom that were highly productive, inclusive, and allowed for additional participation from geographically-distanced TFs. In 2020-2021, the D&Ds were broadened to include monthly four-hour Sunday seminars for extended problem-solving, investigating, and planning.

Some notable project outcomes include:

  • Built the capacity of MTFs to engage in high quality mentoring of prospective mathematics and science teachers (n = 25).
  • Provided licensure/master's degrees for well-prepared secondary mathematics/science teachers (n = 24).
  • Improved the mathematical and scientific knowledge for teaching of MTFs/TFs while strengthening licensure processes at UMass.
  • Connected school districts and teachers with community and university resources for professional development and research.
  • MTFs/TFs completed extended projects of their choosing designed to address cultural STEM connections and social justice issues in mathematics and science in their school communities, producing enduring results in schools and/or communities.
  • Designed and implemented courses for professional licensure in mathematics and science that helped facilitate the construction of a professional licensure program in 5-8 and 8-12 mathematics at the UMass.
  • Facilitated D&D induction sessions that became a highly productive virtual community of practice (VCoP) that, even without support, teachers have vowed to continue.
  • Conducted lesson observations in MTF and TF classrooms as an essential component for informing and supporting teachers? emerging practices in mathematics and science teaching.
  • Supported teachers writing for publication and presenting at professional conferences.
